questions.text: Match the following? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. i. = c, ii. = a, iii. = d, iv. = b

 

i) Heroine = c) Brown sugar

 

ii) Joint = a) Ganja

 

iii) LSD = d) Acid

 

iv) Eve = b) Amphetamine

 

Explanation:

 

  • i. Heroin = c. Brown sugar
    • Heroin is a semi-synthetic opioid also known by street names such as brown sugar, smack, dope, junk.
  • ii. Joint = a. Ganja
    • A joint is a term used for a rolled marijuana cigarette. Ganja is also known as pot, grass, weed, rope, mull, dope, joint, Mary Jane, skunk, hash, reefer.
  • iii. LSD = d. Acid
    • LSD is known by various street names including acid, blotter acid, blue caps, blue dots, brown caps, crackers, purple owle.
  • iv. Eve = b. Amphetamine
    • Methamphetamine and related substances are often referred to as Eve, meth, etc.

 

Educational Objective

 

Street names of narcotic substances

 

  • Ganja is called Pot, grass, weed, rope, mull, dope, joint, Mary Jane, skunk, hash, reefer.
  • Heroin is a semisynthetic opioid also known as brown sugar, smack, dope, junk
  •   Cocaine is called by names like snuff, Rock, Crack, Coke, Snow, Cadillac, White lady
  • Methamphetamine is also called eve, meth etc.
  • LSD is called by names like acid, blotter acid, blue caps, blue dots, brown caps, crackers, purple Owle.
  • Abrus Precatorius is called by names like Indian liquor ice, prayer head, crab's eye, weather plant, gulagunchi, ratti, gunja.
  • Capsaicin is called by names like 'Hunan hand' as it causes burning of fingers.

questions.text:
A concerned mother takes her daughter of 14 years age who was complaining of pain in the private parts to a gynecologist. On eliciting history, the girl admits she had consensual sexual intercourse with a neighbor and refuses to get examined. What should the gynecologist do? (AIIMS MAY 2020)

 

  1. Document informed refusal
  2. Do not inform the police
  3. Counsel the mother and daughter
  4. Examine with necessary force
  5. Inform the police
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 5 are true 

 

This situation involves multiple aspects: legal, ethical, and medical considerations are paramount. Here's why each statement is addressed as true or false in this context:

 

1. Document informed refusal: True. It is essential for medical practitioners to document any refusal of examination or treatment, particularly in sensitive cases involving minors. Documentation should include detailed information about what was explained to the patient and the guardian, and their reasons for refusal, to ensure clarity and legal safeguarding.

 

3. Counsel the mother and daughter: True. The role of a gynecologist includes providing medical counseling, especially when it involves minors and sensitive issues such as sexual activity. Counseling should aim to educate about the health implications of the sexual activity, the benefits of medical examination, and the legal aspects considering the age of consent.

 

5. Inform the police: True. According to laws in many jurisdictions, including India, any sexual activity with a minor, regardless of consent, is considered statutory rape. Medical professionals are mandated reporters, which means they are legally obligated to report such cases to law enforcement to ensure the safety of the minor and adhere to legal statutes.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Do not inform the police: False. The gynecologist has a mandatory obligation to report cases of suspected statutory rape, as non-reporting could be considered a failure of duty and legal non-compliance.

 

4. Examine with necessary force: False. It is illegal and unethical to perform a medical examination against a patient's will, especially in the case of a minor. The patient's autonomy must be respected, and no examination should proceed without consent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Examination of a victim of sexual assault should be done only after the consent of the victim. It is the accused who can be examined without consent, not the victim. Whether the victim agrees for examination or not, the police always have to be informed as there is an allegation of crime of rape (as sex even with consent with a girl <18 years of age will be considered rape)

questions.text: A 32-year-old female had a fight with her husband and was brought dead and an autopsy was performed to find the cause of death. Can you identify the probable cause of death from the image given below? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Throttling

 

The image shows bruises and abrasion on the neck which are strongly suggestive of throttling

 

Manual strangulation (throttling): Compression of neck by hands

 

Autopsy findings in Manual Strangulation (Throttling):

 

  • External findings on the neck:
    • Bruising on the neck. (Especially 6 penny bruises: These are bruises produced  The tips of the fingers, are oval or round and 1.5–2 cm in size)
    • Abrasions of the neck (especially crescent shaped abrasions produced by nails)

 

  • Internal findings in the neck
    • Internal Neck injuries are very significant in throttling like:
    • Extravasation of blood in subcutaneous tissues
    • Tear of platysma or sternomastoid muscles.
    • Hemorrhages in mucous membrane of larynx, epiglottis, and pharynx.
    • Inward compression fracture of hyoid bone
    • Fracture of superior horns of thyroid cartilage

 

Other Options:

 

Option B (Strangulation): Here the word “strangulation” implies ligature strangulation, because we have throttling in other choice. Ligature strangulation would have a ligature mark

 

Option C (Hanging): Hanging would have a ligature mark

 

Option D Mugging: Strangulation by holding the neck of victim in the bend of elbow or knee of assailant. Here the injuries (both internal and external) are minimal. There may be some diffuse abrasion / bruise externally, but it will not be as prominent and localized as shown in question.

 

 

Educational objective

 

Throttling is characterized by bruises and abrasions on the neck caused by manual compression, often accompanied by significant internal injuries.

choices.text: 1 and 4 only

questions.text:
A skull was recovered from a forest. According to inquest papers, woman had gone missing after a fight with her boyfriend a month back. The skull was sent to the forensic research lab. Which of the following would identify it as a female skull? (INICET May 2021)

 

  1. Large frontal and parietal eminence
  2. Heavy cheek bones
  3. Smooth glabella
  4. Square orbits
  5. Narrow mastoid
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1, 3 and 5   

 

Female Skull Characteristics:

 

1. Large frontal and parietal eminence: These are more prominent in females.

 

3. Smooth glabella: Females typically have a smoother glabella compared to males.

 

5. Narrow mastoid: Female mastoid processes are generally narrower and less prominent.

 

These characteristics help in identifying the skull as female.

 

Note - General differences between male and female bones: There are some general features which help to differentiate male and female bones. These are

 

  • Size: Male bones are larger than female bones.
  • Roughness: Male bones are more rougher due to increased muscle attachment areas. Females have smooth features
  • Weight: Male bones are heavier than female bones
  • Articular Surface Size: Male bones may have larger articular surfaces compared to females.
  • Square features: Male have square features, whereas females have rounded features

 

So for individual bones, just remember the specific features, instead of general features

 

Other Options

 

2. Heavy cheek bones: Typical in males, as a general rule, female bones are lighter than male bones.

 

4. Square orbits: Males have squarish features, whereas females have roundish features.

 

Educational objective

 

Most features are larger, rougher, and more prominent in male skull, except frontal eminence, parietal eminence and orbits which are more prominent or larger in females

questions.text: Identify the following post-mortem change. (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Suggillation

 

The image shows post mortem staining on the back, also called suggillation. Post-mortem staining (PMS) is the settling of the blood in the dependent portions of the body after death due to loss of circulation, causing a purplish-red discoloration of the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tattooing: Tattoos appear as distinct, well-defined patterns or designs, often in various colors. Tattoos can be located anywhere on the body and are not necessarily confined to dependent areas. They are typically intentional markings made by injecting ink into the skin.

 

Option C. Putrefaction: The body becomes greenish in colour in putrefaction. Later it becomes blackish.

 

Option D. Decomposition: Same explanation as that of putrefaction

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post Mortem Staining (PMS)

 

  •  It is the settling of the blood in the dependent, portion of the body after death due to loss of circulation, causing a purplish red discoloration of the skin.
  • Other names of PMS are:
    • Hypostasis
    • livor mortis
    • Vibices
    • Suggillation
    • Postmortem Lividity
    • Cadaveric lividity
    • Darkening of death
  •  It is present on dependent areas, but absent on pressure areas as the blood vessels get compressed. In a supine body the pressure areas are back of chest, buttocks etc as these are in the direct contact with ground.

questions.text: Identify the seeds shown in the image below: (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nigella sativa 

 

The seeds shown in the given image are of the plant Nigella sativa. 

 

Other names - black cumin or kalonji.

 

Method of action - Sativa modulates the neuronal release of GABA, glycine, aspartate and glutamate on cultured cortical neurons and also possesses a potent central nervous system (CNS) sedative and analgesic activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tropicana canna: This option is incorrect as Tropicana canna refers to a type of plant known for its large, colorful leaves and flowers, not for its seeds.

 

 

Option C. Datura seeds: Incorrect, as Datura seeds are typically flatter and have a distinct shape compared to Nigella sativa. Datura is also known for its toxic properties and is used in traditional medicine with caution.

 

 

Option D. Opium seeds: Incorrect. Opium seeds likely refer to poppy seeds, which are smaller and have a different texture and appearance compared to Nigella sativa seeds.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nigella sativa, or black cumin, is not only recognized for its unique seed appearance but also for its significant medicinal properties, including sedative and analgesic effects on the central nervous system.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female was brought dead to the casualty. On examination there was frothing from her nose and mouth. What is the likely cause of death? (INICET NOVEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Drowning

 

The image shows frothing from nostrils which is likely to be due to drowning.

 

Postmortem changes of drowning:

 

  • Bloody froth in the airway

  • Water in the stomach and small intestine

  • Water in middle ear

  • Cerebral edema

  • Bloated and cyanosed face

  • Petrous or mastoid hemorrhage.

  • Voluminous / ballooned out lungs

  • Suffused conjunctive, dilated pupils

  • "Washerwoman" changes of the hands (shriveling of the skin) develop when submerged in water for several hours

  • Cutis anserina / goose skin- The contraction of the erector pilorum muscles causes puckering and a grainy appearance of the skin.

  • Cadaveric spasm - Gravel, weed, soil, grass, etc. is firmly held in the clenched hands due to cadaveric spasm. This is a vital sign of antemortem drowning.

  • Rigor mortis - This appears early in cases of a violent antemortem struggle.

  • Diatom test

 

Gettler test can be done to estimate the chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hanging: Typically presents with a ligature mark around the neck, not frothing.

 

Option C. Strangulation: Often shows signs of external trauma to the neck, such as bruising or fractures, but not frothing.

 

Option D. Traumatic asphyxia: This results from severe chest compression, leading to petechiae and cyanosis but not usually frothing from the nose and mouth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frothing from the nose and mouth, along with other specific postmortem findings, strongly suggests drowning as the cause of death.

choices.text: Only the roots of this plant are poisonous
Drug of choice for poisoning is Atropine
Mitha zeher is one of the varieties of this plant

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding the picture given below? (AIIMS May 2018,)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Only the roots of this plant are poisonous

 

The image shows aconite, a highly toxic plant. All parts of the aconite plant are poisonous, not just the roots.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Causes AV block: Correct statement. Aconite poisoning causes AV block due to its effects on the heart.

 

Option C. Drug of choice for poisoning is Atropine: Correct statement. Atropine is used to counteract the bradycardia and AV block caused by aconite poisoning.

 

Option D. Mitha zeher is one of the varieties of this plant: Correct statement. "Mitha zeher" is a common name for aconite.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aconite:

 

  • All parts of the plant are poisonous.
  • Aconite is also called as - monkhood, mitha zeher, bish, and bikh.
  • Method of poisoning - It is a cardiac poison and causes AV block, bradycardia.
  • Treatment of choice - Atropine

questions.text: Identify the person to whom the First-hand knowledge rule is applicable? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Common witness

 

The first-hand knowledge rule applies to a common witness who gives evidence about the facts directly observed by them. This rule ensures that the testimony provided is based on direct observation and personal experience rather than hearsay or second-hand information.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Handwriting expert: An expert witness who provides testimony based on specialized knowledge or expertise, rather than direct personal observation of the facts in question.

 

Option C. Doctor: A medical professional who may provide expert testimony based on their medical expertise, rather than direct observation of the facts in question.

 

Option D. A hostile witness is a witness who appears to be refusing to fully testify in support of the person who called them or testifies in a way that significantly differs from their pre-trial.

 

Note : An expert witness is a person with extensive experience or knowledge in a specific field or discipline beyond that expected from a layperson. The expert witness's duty is to apply their expertise to give a professional opinion to the tribunal or court on particular matters in dispute. Doctors, handwriting/ fingerprints/ firearms experts come under this category.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-hand knowledge rule ensures that the testimony provided by a common witness is based on direct observation and personal experience, thereby maintaining the integrity and reliability of the evidence presented in court.

questions.text: Identify the type of physical restraint given in the picture below: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hog tie

 

This type of physical restraint is called Hog tying. The method involves restraining a prisoner's hands behind his back, restraining his feet and then coupling the hand and feet restraints from the back.

 

Other Options

 

Option A: Choke/carotid hold: A choke hold is a grappling hold that critically reduces or prevents either air or blood from passing through the neck of an opponent. It is commonly used in martial arts and law enforcement but is not shown in the image.

 

Option B: Carotid sleeper hold: This hold is a type of choke hold that targets the carotid arteries to induce unconsciousness. It is also used in self-defence and law enforcement but does not match the restraint method shown in the image.

 

Option D: Bar arm: A bar arm restraint involves using the arm to apply pressure to the neck or back, typically in law enforcement. It does not match the method of tying hands and feet together as seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective

 

Hog tying involves restraining a person’s hands behind their back, restraining their feet, and coupling the hand and feet restraints together from behind, often used as a form of torture or control.

 

Additional Information

 

Torture

 

  1. Wet submarino/ Latina  – suffocation of head in liquids/ dirty liquids

 

  1. Dry submarino: Plastic bag around face

 

  1. Telefono – beating on ear by hands

 

  1. Falanga (Bastinado): Beating on feet

 

  1. Parrot’s perch – rod placed below knees , upside down , hands tied to rod



 

6. Planton – person made to stand for long hours

             

7. Saw horse – victim sits on sharp object → injury to perineal area

 

 

8. Hog tie – Restraining a prisoner's hands behind his back, restraining his feet and then coupling the hand and feet restraints from the back.

 

9. Ghotna – wooden log rolled over the legs

 

10. Chepuwa – wooden log is compressed on legs

 

11. Black slave – hot metal rod in anus

 

12. Electric cattle prod – electric current to sensitive parts (nipple, genitalia)

choices.text: Atropine and neostigmine are very useful in the management of krait bite
Neostigmine and ventilatory support are used in treatment along with ASV
ASV is the mainstay of treatment
Current ASV in India is less effective against humped pit viper

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the management of snakebite in India? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atropine and neostigmine are very useful in the management of krait bite 

 

Neostigmine (along with atropine) can be used for neurotoxic snakes (both cobra and krait). But the usefulness is much less in krait bite, and much more in cobra bite.

 

  • Mechanism of Neostigmine: Neostigmine is the inhibitor of acetylcholinesterase enzyme. So, it will act as an antidote to acetylcholinesterase enzyme component of cobra and krait venom
  • Why Neostigmine is less useful in Krait: Krait, in addition also have some toxins that inhibit the release of acetylcholine from presynaptic terminal at neuromuscular junction. Neostigmine will not be helpful to counter the effect of these toxins. 
  • Why Atropine used with Neostigmine: As neostigmine increases the amount of acetylcholine, both nicotinic and muscarinic effects occur. But to treat snake bite we need only nicotinic effects at neuromuscular junction. Atropine is an antimuscarinic agent and helps to counter the muscarinic effects of nicotine, especially bradycardia. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Neostigmine and ventilatory support are used in treatment along with ASV:
This statement is true. Neostigmine can be part of the management for neurotoxic snake envenomations, and ventilatory support may be necessary if there is significant respiratory compromise. ASV (Anti-Snake Venom) is also used as it neutralizes the venom.

 

Option C. ASV is the mainstay of treatment: True. ASV remains the primary treatment for snakebite envenomations in India, effectively neutralizing the venom of various snake species.

 

Option D. Current ASV in India is less effective against humped pit viper: This is true. There are regional variations in the efficacy of ASV based on the specific snake species prevalent in those regions, and ASV formulations may be less effective against certain species, such as the humped pit viper.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of snake bite:

 

  • First Aid treatment have limited role. Reassure the patient, immobilize the limb and keep it below the heart level. Light pressure can be applied in neurotoxic snakes.
  • Anti-snake venom (ASV) is the main treatment for snake bite. It contains antivenom against the 4 common poisonous snakes in India (Cobra, Krait, Russel’s viper and saw scaled viper). It does not contain antivenom against humped pit viper, which is found in some states of India, but still can be partially effective in it due to cross antibodies formation. 
  • Treatment in addition to ASV:
    • Vasculotoxic symptoms: Dialysis and Blood Transfusion
    • Musculotoxic symptoms: Dialysis
    • Neurotoxic snakes: Ventilation and Neostigmine (along with atropine)

 

Other Options: Explained above

questions.text:
You are working as a casualty medical officer. A 16-year-old girl is brought to the casualty by her parents after alleged sexual assault, the girl refuses physical examination. Which of the following would you do?

  1. Start treatment for STD and pregnancy

  2. Inform the police

  3. Record refusal of consent

  4. Take vaginal samples

  5. Start medical examination
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 2 and 3

 

As the girl is under 18 years of age, the medical practitioner must follow the guidelines of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act 2012, which include:

 

1. Start treatment for STD and pregnancy: The medical officer should begin prophylactic treatment for sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and pregnancy to ensure the girl's health and safety.

 

2. Inform the police: It is mandatory to report the alleged sexual assault to the police, as it involves a minor.

 

3. Record refusal of consent: The refusal of the girl to undergo a physical examination must be documented properly to respect her autonomy and legal rights.

 

Other Options:

 

4. Take vaginal samples: This should not be done without the girl's consent, as it violates her autonomy and legal rights.

 

5. Start medical examination: Any physical examination must be consented to by the patient. In this case, the girl has refused consent, so the examination should not proceed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

As the girl is under 18 years of age, as per POCSO (The Protection of Children from Sexual Offences) act 2012, the medical practitioner should start treatment for STI & pregnancy, inform the police and record the refusal of consent for examination

choices.text: Child Welfare Committee

questions.text: A young girl refuses to go to Mathematics class everyday citing abnormal excuses. It was discovered by the principal that the mathematics teacher was touching her genitalia inappropriately. The duty of the principal is to report this to?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Police

 

Explanation:

 

Under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, the principal should refer to Section 19 which states that “Any person who has apprehension that an offence under this Act is likely to be committed or has knowledge that such an offence has been committed shall provide such information to the Special Juvenile Police Unit or the local police.”

 

Other options

 

Option A) Magistrate, Option C) child welfare committee, Option D) Parents: According to POCSO Act, Article 19, the immediate duty is to inform the police when there is knowledge or apprehension of a child being sexually abused. Others can be informed later.

 

Educational Objective

 

POCSO Act Provisions

 

  • Section 19 of the Act makes it mandatory for any person including the child to approach the police in case of an apprehension that an offence under the Act is likely to be committed or "has the knowledge" that such an act has been committed.

 

 The POCSO act defines a child as any person below eighteen years of age. It defines various forms of sexual offenses which include:

 

  • ﻿﻿﻿Sexual harassment - Threatening
  • ﻿﻿﻿Sexual assault - Any act with sexual intent that involves physical contact without penetration.
  • ﻿﻿﻿Aggravated sexual assault - Similar to sexual assault along with the criteria explained under the term aggravated
  • ﻿﻿﻿Penetrative sexual assault - An act with sexual intent that involves physical penetration of the penis or any object into the vagina, mouth, urethra, or anus.
  • ﻿﻿﻿Aggravated penetrative sexual assault - Similar to penetrative sexual assault along with the criteria explained under the term aggravated
  • ﻿﻿﻿Pornography

questions.text: Treatment of choice for acute arsenic poisoning is? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Dimercaprol

 

Dimercaprol is a traditional chelating agent of choice for acute arsenic poisoning. Though now DMSA and DMPS are considered better, as they can be given orally and have lower toxicity. Amongst the given choices, dimercaprol is best answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ipecac: Ipecac is rapidly acting anti-emetic. Earlier it was sometimes used to remove different types of unabsorbed poisons in GIT, but now it is no longer recommended due to limited benefits

 

Option B. Penicillamine: Though it can be used in arsenic, but not a preferred agent. It is preferred chelator for copper.

 

Option C. Activated charcoal: Not useful as it does not adsorb arsenic and other heavy metals

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of Acute Arsenic poisoning

 

  • Hemodynamic stabilization for significant GI losses (vomiting and diarrhea)
  • Gastric lavage is done repeatedly with large amount of warm water and milk;
  • Chelating Agents
    • Chelating agents are useful in acute arsenic poisoning, but have very limited role in chronic arsenic poisoning
    • There are three chelating agents useful in acute arsenic poisoning:
      1. British Anti Lewisite (BAL, aka dimercaprol, dimercaptopropanol): available in IM route. Traditionally BAL was used most commonly for As, but now DMSA and DMPS are considered better, as they can be given orally and have lower toxicity.
      2. Dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA, aka succimer): available Orally
      3. Dimercaptopropanesulfonic acid (DMPS, aka Dimerval): available Oral, IM and IV. DMPS is agent of choice for acute As poisoning.

questions.text: Identify the type of skull fracture sustained in a motorcycle accident? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hinge fracture

 

Image shows a transverse fracture of the base of the skull that completely splits it and divide it into two halves, each moving independently of each other like a hinge (‘nodding face’ sign).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Depressed fracture of skull: When a portion of fractured bone is driven inwards to a distance equivalent to the thickness of the skull table, it is known as depressed fracture. The picture in the question have a transverse fracture dividing the base of the skull and is not a depressed fracture hence this option is incorrect.

 

Option C) Pond fracture is the other name of pediatric depressed skull fracture. It is primarily due to increased plasticity of the immature skeleton in young children. The picture in the question have a transverse fracture dividing the base of the skull and is not a depressed fracture hence this option is incorrect.

 

Option D) Comminuted fracture of skull: is when two or more intersecting lines of fracture divide the bone into three or more fragments resembling a spider web or mosaic pattern this is not the case in this picture hence this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

‘Hinge’ (also called Motorcyclist):

 

  • linear fracture passes across the middle cranial fossa, separating the skull base into Ant and post halves,
  • Occurs Severe Force to side of head (e.g. in motorcycle accidents).
  • Such fractures are commonly associated with injuries of the brain stem, especially pontomedullary tears.

questions.text: Criminal responsibility of Insane is defined in: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. McNaughten's Rule

 

“McNaughten’s Rule” also known as “Legal test of insanity”, “right or wrong test” is the legal standard for determining criminal responsibility in cases of insanity.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Curren's rule: of 1964 states that an accused person is not criminally responsible, if at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirements of the law, as a result of mental disease or defect.

 

Option C. Durham 's rule: of 1954 States that an accused person is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act is the product of mental disease or mental defect.

 

Option D. American law institute test: (1972) A person is not responsible for the crime, if at the time of committing it, he lacks adequate capacity to appreciate the criminality of his conduct or to adjust it to the requirements of the law.

 

Educational Objective:

 

McNaughten's rule is defined by section 84 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC)

 

It states that "A person of unsound mind is not liable for an act."

 

It implies that the defendant was unable to distinguish between right and wrong or otherwise didn't understand what they did because of a "disease of the mind."

questions.text: Identify the plant given in the image below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Argemone Mexicana

 

  • The plant in the image is Argemone Mexicana.
  • It is also called as Mexican prickly poppy.
  • Oil extract can cause Epidemic dropsy characterized by vomiting, diarrhea, edema of the feet, and generalized anasarca.
  • Identification: Yellow flowers

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Datura alba: Datura alba, also known as white datura, has large trumpet-shaped white flowers and is a different plant with its own toxic properties, primarily affecting the nervous system.

 

 

Option C. Abrus precatorius: Abrus precatorius, commonly known as Rosary pea or jequirity, has distinctive red seeds with a black spot. The plant is different from Argemone mexicana.

 

 

Option D. Erthyroxylum coca: Erthyroxylum coca is the plant from which cocaine is derived. It has small white flowers and red berries, and does not resemble Argemone mexicana.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The plant Argemone mexicana, identifiable by its yellow flowers and spiny leaves, is known for its toxic oil extract which can cause Epidemic dropsy.

questions.text: All of the following features are seen in chronic arsenic poisoning except? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Luminous vomit

 

Luminous vomiting is a feature of yellow phosphorus poisoning, not arsenic poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Raindrop pigmentation: This is a characteristic skin finding in chronic arsenic poisoning.

 

Option B. Peripheral neuritis: Peripheral neuritis is a common neurological manifestation of chronic arsenic exposure.

 

Option C. Mees line: Mees lines (transverse white lines on nails) are indicative of chronic arsenic poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Features seen in chronic arsenic poisoning:

 

1. Peripheral neuropathy (neuritis):         

It can occur in Arsenic , Thallium , Mercury, and Lead.                                  

Lead: Mainly motor, little bit sensory neuropathy                                                     

Arsenic, Thallium, mercury: mainly sensory, little bit motor neuropathy 

 

2) Skin symptoms:

- Hypopigmentation initially

- Rain Drop Pigmentation as shown below

 

 

- Peculiar skin rash – resembles Addison’s disease , Fading measles rash

- Hyperkeratosis of palms & soles as shown below:

 

3) Nails: Aldrich Mees Lines

Transverse whitish lines on nails (seen is Arsenic, and Thallium)

 

 

 

4) Hair: Alopecia seen in Mercury, Arsenic, Thallium (Mnemonic: Hair on MAT)

 

5) GIT: Vomiting , Diarrhoea , pain abdomen

 

6) Liver: Jaundice , Hepatomegaly , Fatty liver , Cirrhosis

 

7) Blackfoot disease: Coagulation in Peripheral blood vessels leading to Gangrene of periphery

 

8) Malignancy of almost any body part

questions.text: What is the causative agent for Hooch tragedy? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Methanol

 

Hooch tragedy is due to the consumption of adulterated liquor containing methanol. Methanol is a toxic form of alcohol that can cause severe health issues including blindness, metabolic acidosis, and death when ingested.

 

Hooch

 

  • Definition: It is ethyl alcohol illegally adulterated with other harmful substances
  • Methanol as adulterant: A common harmful adulterant in hooch is methanol
  • Sources of methanol in Ethanol: There are two ways by which methanol gets added in the ethanol:
    • Added deliberately to ethanol due to its low price or
    • Produced during ethanol production (fermentation): Methanol can get naturally produced along with ethanol during the production of ethanol by fermentation. Usually it gets removed by distillation, but in local and illegal production, the distillation is of poor quality.
  • Hooch tragedy in India: In India, local alcohol is made illegally from cane sugar, is sold very cheap for a plastic pouch or glass. In Bihar and some other states, it has resulted in deaths of multiple people at different times

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphorus: Phosphorus poisoning usually occurs due to ingestion of substances like rodenticides or fireworks and is not associated with hooch tragedies.

 

Option B. Mercury: Mercury poisoning occurs from exposure to mercury or its compounds and is not linked to hooch tragedies.

 

Option C. Ethanol: Ethanol is the intended product of alcoholic beverages. It is not the cause of hooch tragedies unless it is adulterated with toxic substances like methanol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hooch tragedies occur due to the consumption of illicitly brewed liquor contaminated with methanol, a toxic form of alcohol that can cause severe health effects including death.

questions.text:
Arrange symptoms as in their order of appearance as seen in iron toxicity:(INICET MAY 2021)

  1. Pyloric stricture
  2. Asymptomatic phase
  3. Gastrointestinal bleeding
  4. Liver failure and hypoglycemia
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3 → 2 → 4 → 1

 

Iron toxicity progresses through several stages, each with distinct symptoms that appear in a specific order. The stages are:

 

 

Treatment of Iron toxicity – Deferoxamine

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron toxicity progresses through distinct stages, starting with gastrointestinal irritation and bleeding, followed by an asymptomatic phase, then liver failure and hypoglycemia, and finally, bowel obstruction leading to pyloric stricture.

choices.text: Examination by Male doctor with female attendant

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl was raped by her neighbor. She presents to the hospital with 25 weeks of pregnancy. What should not be done? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Termination of pregnancy with her consent by a Gynecologist

 

According to the MTP Act, the termination of pregnancy due to rape is allowed only upto 24 weeks. Also, since this girl is a minor (< 18 years) the consent of the guardian is required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Examination by Male doctor with female attendant: Male doctor can always examine a female patient, if a female attendant is present

 

Option B) Vaginal swab examination is not necessary: Evidence of rape remains only till 96 hours. Here pregnancy is 25 weeks, so vaginal swab will not help to detect semen

 

Option C) Confirm pregnancy by USG: After 21 weeks the pregnancy can be confirmed by simple palpation of fetal parts. USG may be done for other reasons, but not to confirm pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

MTP ACT (Latest amendment 2021)

choices.text: Frontal and maxillary sinuses are larger
Frontal and parietal eminences are larger

questions.text: Which of the following trait is a feature of the female skull? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Frontal and parietal eminences are larger

 

Remember: In general, most features are larger and more prominent in males. However, there are three features which are exceptionally larger or more prominent in females. Just remember these:

 

  • Frontal Eminence is more prominent in females 
  • Parietal Eminence is more prominent in females
  • Orbits are larger in females

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Larger teeth: Incorrect. Male skulls typically have larger teeth compared to females.

 

Option B. Frontal and maxillary sinuses are larger: Incorrect. These sinuses are generally larger in males.

 

Option D. Supratympanic crest is present: Incorrect. This feature is more commonly found in male skulls.

 

Educational Objective:

 

General differences between male and female bones: There are some general features which help to differentiate male and female bones. These are applicable to most bones, hence no need to remember separately for each bone. These are

 

Size: Male bones tend are larger than female bones.

 

Texture: The texture of male bones can be rougher and more rugged due to increased muscle attachment areas.

 

Articular Surface Size: Male bones may have larger articular surfaces compared to females.

 

Bone Markings: Bony markings where muscles and ligaments attach are more prominent in males.

 

So for individual bones, just remember the specific features, instead of general features

questions.text: A 51-year-old bomb blast victim is brought to the casualty with life-threatening injuries. There was a lot of chaos and no one was available to sign consent for emergency surgery. Despite surgery the patient died. The doctor is not responsible under which doctrine? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Doctrine of anticipation 

 

Core Concept

 

Operating without consent in life threatening emergency

 

  • IPC Section 92 - Act done in good faith for benefit of a person without consent
  • This means that the doctor can perform life-saving procedures in a patient with life-threatening injuries without obtaining consent specially if delay in treatment in order to obtain consent would result in harm to the patient. 
  • This is also called as the doctrine of anticipation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Res ipsa loquitur:

 

  • It is a Latin phrase for "the thing speaks for itself."
  • Here the Negligence is so obvious that it does not require expert testimony or specific evidence to establish a breach of the standard of care.
  • The event is unusual and wouldn't occur without negligence

 

Option C. Doctrine of extended consent: suppose some another pathology is discovered during surgery then another consent is taken. This is called doctrine of extended consent

 

Option D. Doctrine of conjugated consent: Consent for multiple procedures given together

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Doctrine of anticipation," which permits medical interventions without prior consent in emergencies where delays could result in harm or death to the patient. This doctrine is crucial in understanding the legal protections afforded to doctors making critical decisions under duress and with the intent to save lives.

The age of fusion are:

questions.text: Fingerprint develops in how many weeks of intrauterine life? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 12-16

 

Fingerprints begin to form between 12 to 16 weeks of intrauterine life. By this stage, the basic patterns of the ridges on the skin are established. The formation continues, and fingerprints are complete by approximately 24 weeks of intrauterine life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fingerprints start developing between 12-16 weeks of intrauterine life and are completed by 24 weeks, providing a unique identification for the individual that remains unchanged throughout their life.

choices.text: Orbicularis oculi, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb
Orbicularis oculi, neck, facial muscles, upper limb, thorax
Neck, muscles of eyelid, upper limb, thorax
Neck, muscles of eyelid, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb

questions.text: In what sequence do muscles develop rigor mortis, progressing from early to late? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Orbicularis oculi, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb

 

Nysten's rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in various muscle groups.

 

Rigor mortis begins from the head and progresses down the body. The order of appearance of rigor mortis is:

 

  1. Myocardium
  2. Eyelids
  3. Neck and lower jaw
  4. Face
  5. Chest
  6. Upper extremities
  7. Abdomen
  8. Legs
  9. Fingers and toes

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rigor mortis

 

Rigor mortis is the post-mortem stiffening and contraction of muscles in the body, resulting from the depletion of energy stores, usually becoming noticeable a few hours after death and gradually resolving over time.”

 

  • It first affects the involuntary muscles first starting with the myocardium
  • Nysten’s law deals with the progression of rigor mortis in voluntary muscles
  • Order of appearance of Rigor mortis in different organs:

questions.text: Identify the injury in the image below: (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Abrasion

 

The given image shows the superficial injury and is not penetrating the full thickness of the epidermis, bleeding is also not seen, all these indicates towards abrasion.

 

Abrasion

 

  • Abrasions are superficial injuries of the skin and visceral linings in the body, resulting in a break in the continuity of tissue.
  • It does not penetrate the full thickness of the epidermis.
  • Only epidermis (mostly partial epidermis) is involved.
  • No bleeding.
  • No scar formation.
  • All abrasions are simple hurt except corneal abrasions (impairs vision and hence a grievous hurt).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Laceration is a deep wound produced by the tearing of soft body tissue. This type of wound is often irregular and jagged.

 

Option C. Bruise is caused by a direct blow to the body that can cause damage to the surface of the skin and to deeper tissues. It causes rupture of capillaries of the skin leading to the bruise

 

Option D. Imprint or impact abrasion happens when large force is applied over lesser period of time, also results in crushing epithelium eg.: Tyre mark, recoil abrasion, radiator grill mark.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Abrasions are superficial injuries involving only the epidermis, with no bleeding and no scar formation, and are typically simple hurts except for corneal abrasions.

choices.text: Post mortem lividity

questions.text: The postmortem change seen in the image below corresponds to which of the following?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Marbling

 

Explanation: In the above picture superficial veins are visible on the dead body which is characteristic of Marbling. Hydrogen sulphides gas produced by decomposing tissues combine with Hb to form sulph-meth-haemoglobin. This sulph-meth-haemoglobin stains the tissues and vessels producing a greenish black color called marbling.

 

 

Other options

 

Option B) Algor mortis: Algor mortis refers to the postmortem cooling of the body. After death, the body temperature gradually decreases until it reaches the ambient temperature hence this option is incorrect.

 

Option C) Rigor mortis: Rigor mortis is the stiffening of muscles that occurs after death due to ATP depletion in the muscles.

 

Option D) Post mortem lividity is a passive process of blood accumulating within the blood vessels in the dependent parts of the body as a result of gravity, causing a discoloration of the skin that varies from pink to dark purplish. The pale looking areas on the skin are the pressure areas. The below image of PM Lividity

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Marbling

 

  1. Marbling is a characteristic color change occurring in Putrefaction in which the superficial veins become visible on the skin due to staining by Hemoglobin or sulphmethhaemoglobin
  2. Mechanism of color change in putrefaction:
  1. Direct staining by Hemoglobin (Hb): Lyses of RBCs occur in putrefaction which releases the Hb. This Hb itself stains the tissues and vessels producing a reddish brown coloration which later becomes greenish black.
  2. Staining by Sulph-meth-haemoglobin: Hydrogen sulphides gas produced by decomposing tissues combine with Hb to form sulph-meth-haemoglobin. This sulph-meth-haemoglobin stains the tissues and vessels producing a greenish black color.
  1. This greenish black staining of superficial veins appears as prominent lines on the skin called Marbling
  2. Marbling is distinctly appreciable in the superficial veins of abdomen, shoulders, chest and inguinal region.
  3. Marbling starts in 24 hours and becomes prominent in about 36–48 hours after death in summer

questions.text: The punishment for the death of a patient by spurious drug? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Life imprisonment 

 

  • The punishment for the death of a patient by a spurious drug is life imprisonment as it leads to grievous hurt which is punishable by life imprisonment as per Drugs and Cosmetics act.
  • Spurious or imitation drug products are drug formulations manufactured. concealing the true identity of the product and made to resemble another drug, especially some popular brand, to deceive the buyer and cash on the popularity of original product.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, the distribution of spurious drugs that result in death constitutes grievous hurt, warranting severe legal consequences including life imprisonment.

questions.text: A patient alleges negligence by a surgeon and sues him for the same. In case of professional misconduct, the patient's records on demand should be provided within? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 3 days

 

In case of professional misconduct, the patient's records on demand should be provided within 72 hours/ 3 days.

 

The treating doctor has to maintain the medical records of the patients for a period of three years as per the regulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MEDICAL RECORDS

 

1. Duration of retention of records –

  • Digital Records – 10 years
  • Hard copy – 
  • OPD patients: 3 years
  • Indoor patients: 3 years
  • MLC: 10 years

2. Time to provide records – 3 days

3. What if records not maintained – punished for infamous conduct

questions.text: A gynecologist performs a hysterectomy for endometrial carcinoma. Despite the adequate precaution, the ureter was injured intraoperatively. The gynecologist is not held responsible under? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Medical maloccurence 

 

The gynecologist cannot be held responsible for the above act under medical maloccurence.

 

Medical maloccurence/Inevitable Accident: 

 

  • It is defined as an unfavorable outcome, but not resulting from malpractice.
  • Despite giving best treatment patient may fail to respond properly or may suffer some adverse reactions of the drug leading to temporary or permanent deformities. This is known as a medical maloccurence/inevitable accident.
  • If the doctor can prove this before the court, it will be an absolute defense against malpractice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Novus actus interveniens: This legal term refers to a new intervening act that breaks the chain of causation, leading to a result that might not have been foreseeable. This does not apply here as the injury was directly related to the surgical procedure, not an external unrelated event.

 

Option C. Res ipsa loquitor: Latin for "the thing speaks for itself," this doctrine applies in cases where the injury would not typically occur without negligence. This option would suggest a presumption of negligence because such injuries usually do not occur without a breach in the standard of care. However, the context given indicates precautions were taken, so this is not the best answer.

 

Option D. Physician error: This implies a mistake made by the physician that could lead to legal liability. In this scenario, it was noted that all standard precautions were followed, thus excluding this option as the appropriate answer given that no specific error or negligence was cited.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medical maloccurence is critical to understand that not all adverse outcomes in medicine result from negligence. Some are inherent risks of medical procedures despite the highest standards of care. Recognizing this helps in managing patient expectations and can protect healthcare providers in cases where complications arise despite proper precautions.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male addicted to recreational drugs, smoking and alcohol came to the OPD with complaints of excessive beating of heart and palpitations. On examination, there was episodic tachycardia and occasional extrasystole. Ophthalmic examination showed visual field defects. Which of the drugs is the likely cause?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cocaine

 

This is a sympathomimetic features (tachycardia, palpitation, arrhythmia like extrasystole) which are typical features of cocaine. Visual field defects can also occur with cocaine (due to vasoconstriction, and ischemia) though it is not common.

 

Cocaine is a sympathomimetic drug and has stimulant effects on CNS and CVS:

 

  • Agitation and Restlessness
  • Tachycardia / Palpitations
  • Hypertension
  • Dilated Pupils
  • Profuse Sweating
  • Hyperthermia
  • Paranoia and hallucinations.
  • Serious CVS Effects: Arrhythmias, Extrasystole, Myocardial Infarction
  • Seizures, Confusion 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nicotine:

 

  • While nicotine can cause tachycardia and palpitations, but they are more pronounced and more common feature of cocaine.
  • Extrasystole are not a typical effect of nicotine use.
  • Nicotine does not cause visual Field Defects

 

Option C. Cannabis:

 

  • Cannabis usually causes mild symptoms, and mainly in CNS (Euphoria, altered perception, impaired cognitive function)
  • Tachycardia caused by cannabis is mild, not arrhythmias or palpitation
  • It does not cause visual field defects

 

Option D. Atropine:

 

  • Atropine is not typically a recreational drug.
  • Atropine causes moderate and controlled tachycardia, but not “episodic” tachycardia or extrasystole. Palpitations are more likely with cocaine as it is sympathomimetic.
  • Atropine can cause temporary mydriasis, but not visual field defects

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine is a sympathomimetic drug that causes significant stimulant effects on the CNS and CVS, leading to symptoms such as tachycardia, palpitations, arrhythmias, and, occasionally, visual field defects due to vasoconstriction and ischemia.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman accuses her office colleague of spiking her drink and raping her. Which test can be used to detect vaginal cells on a person who is accused of rape? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lugol's

 

Lugol's iodine test

 

Aim – It detects the vaginal cells present on the penis of a rape accused.

 

Method - A filter paper is used to swab the penis of the accused. This paper is then treated with Lugol's iodine solution. Vaginal epithelial cells, which contain glycogen, will react with the iodine to produce a brown color, indicating the presence of vaginal cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Florence: Florence test is used for the detection of semen. It is not relevant for detecting vaginal cells.

 

Option B. Barberio: Barberio test is used to detect spermine in semen. It is not useful for identifying vaginal cells.

 

Option D. Precipitin: Precipitin test is used for species identification to determine if the biological material is of human origin. It does not detect vaginal cells specifically.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lugol's iodine test is used to detect vaginal cells on the penis of a rape accused by identifying glycogen-containing epithelial cells, which turn brown when exposed to Lugol's iodine solution.

questions.text: A rape victim is brought to the casualty of a government hospital for examination. Within what time should a vaginal swab be taken to look for the presence of spermatozoa? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Within 72 hours

 

Spermatozoa can be demonstrated only if a vaginal swab is taken within 72 hours of an assault.

 

Semen can be demonstrated on evidence on the outside of the body and on materials such as clothing upto 96 hours.

 

Educational Objective

 

Presence of spermatozoa and other microorganisms

 

•Spermatozoa remain motile in the vagina for 6-8 hours, occasionally up to 12 hours.

•Nonmotile forms can be detected for about 24 hours, rarely up to 48-72 hours.

•Detection involves aspirating vaginal contents and examining under a microscope.

•Motile sperms suggest recent intercourse; nonmotile sperms indicate a broader time frame (12-72 hours).

•Intact spermatozoa are rarely found in the vagina after 72 hours.

•Seminal fluid detection from vasectomized males requires prostatic acid phosphatase demonstration.

•P30, a semen-specific glycoprotein, is used as a screening test, detectable in vaginal fluid for about 27 hours.

questions.text: Match the postmortem findings and their time of appearance:(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

 

Postmortem changes occur in a sequential manner and can be used to estimate the time since death. The matching of these findings with their respective times of appearance is as follows:

 

  1. Adipocere formation
    • Time of appearance: 8-10 days
    • Explanation: Adipocere, also known as grave wax, is a postmortem change that occurs when body fat undergoes a transformation into a waxy substance in a moist environment. This process typically begins around 8-10 days after death.
  2. Relaxation of urethral sphincter
    • Time of appearance: 24 hrs
    • Explanation: After death, muscle relaxation, including the relaxation of the urethral sphincter, occurs due to the cessation of neural activity and muscle tone, typically around 24 hours postmortem.
  3. Marbling of veins
    • Time of appearance: 2-3 days
    • Explanation: Marbling refers to the appearance of greenish-black discoloration along the veins due to the breakdown of hemoglobin and the production of hydrogen sulphide gas by bacteria. This occurs approximately 2-3 days after death.
  4. Liquefaction of tissues
    • Time of appearance: 4-5 days
    • Explanation: Tissue liquefaction is a stage of decomposition where tissues start to break down into a liquid form. This process typically begins around 4-5 days postmortem.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amongst postmortem findings:

 

  • Adipocere formation is by 8-10 days
  • Relaxation of urethral sphincter is by 24 hrs.
  • Marbling of veins is by 2-3 days
  • Liquefaction of tissues is by 4-5 days

questions.text: Identify the image shown below. (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Gunshot wound

 

The given image is of a gunshot wound.

 

Features of gunshot wound:

 

  • Central round hole with surrounding soot soiling.

  • Burnt hairs (singeing).

  • Punctate skin lesions from powder particles (tattooing).

  • Bevelling of edges (Exit Wounds)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tattooing: While tattooing refers to punctate skin lesions caused by powder particles in gunshot wounds, it alone does not describe the entirety of the image shown.

 

Option C. Arsenic poisoning: Arsenic poisoning typically causes symptoms like skin changes, but not the characteristic central hole and surrounding soot seen in gunshot wounds.

 

Option D. Graze wound: A graze wound is typically a superficial wound caused by the bullet skimming the surface of the skin, which looks different from the wound shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A gunshot wound can be identified by its central round hole, surrounding soot, singeing of hairs, tattooing from powder particles, and bevelling of the wound edges.

questions.text: Identify the plant which produces a toxin of abuse potential? (AIIMS May 2019)

questions.text: In gunshot injury to skull with entry wound at right temporal region surrounded by abrasion collar & tattooing and an exit wound at left temporal region along with metal fragments of bullet inside the bullet track, what can be used to determine the range of firing? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hair  

 

The singeing of hair, along with blackening and tattooing, can be used to determine the range of firing in gunshot injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Bullet pieces: They can be present irrespective of the distance

 

Option C) Blood: Not helpful to determine distance

 

Option D) Clothes: Not helpful as the bullet wound is on head. In other body parts clothes would have been helpful

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entry Wound features:

 

  • Contact Shot: Singeing, blackening and tattooing present just on the margin; not around the wound. Very minimally visible.
  • Close Shot: Singeing, blackening and tattooing present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent)
  • Intermediate Range: Only Tattooing present around the wound
  • Distant range: None of these present around the wound.

choices.text: All of the above

questions.text: Out of the options given below, what is the cause of death in smoke inhalation? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anemic hypoxia

 

Smoke contains multiple substances, of which the most significant component is carbon monoxide (CO). CO can cause both anemic hypoxia as well as histotoxic hypoxia, but predominant cause is anemic hypoxia. Mechanism of hypoxia by CO:

 

  • Anemic Hypoxia by CO: CO combines with hb to form COHb) producing anemic hypoxia (blood O2-carrying capacity is reduced)
  • Histotoxic Hypoxia by CO: While the primary impact of CO is on blood oxygen transport, the presence of COHb can also interfere with cellular respiration at the tissue level. COHb affects mitochondrial function and the electron transport chain, disrupting the cells' ability to utilize the oxygen that is delivered to them.

 

Other options

 

Option A) Histotoxic hypoxia occurs when cells can’t effectively use the available oxygen

due to interference with crucial cellular processes. CO causes histotoxic hypoxia also but the main cause of death is anemic hypoxia. A typical example of histotoxic hypoxia is cyanide poisoning.

 

Option B) Ischemic hypoxia results from inadequate circulation due to conditions such as heart failure and hypoxia in the setting of shock.

 

Option D) All of the above it is incorrect as CO may cause anemic and histotoxic hypoxia but not ischemic hypoxia

 

Educational objective

 

Anemic hypoxia

 

  • Anemic hypoxia is hypoxia  caused by the decreased O2-carrying capacity of blood. It can occur due to two reasons:
    • Hb concentration is low, or
    • Hb concentration may be normal, but it is not able to bind to O2. It can occur due to following conditions:
      • CO Poisoning: It has a higher affinity for Hb than O2 forming COHb.
      • Methemoglobinemia: Methemoglobin is a form of Hb where the iron is in the ferric state (Fe3+) instead of the normal ferrous state (Fe2+). Methemoglobin cannot bind to oxygen effectively.
      • Certain Genetic Hemoglobin Disorders altering the structure of Hb, e.g.

Sickle cell anemia, thalassemia.

questions.text: Match the following: (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. i-3, ii-4, iii-1, iv-2 

 

i. Mummification - Image 3. It is a method of embalming the dead body. It occurs in the absence of moisture in the air and continuous action of dry or warmed air.

 

ii. Adipocere - Image 4. It forms under warm and humid weather due to hydrolysis of lipids.

 

iii. Marbling - Image 1. In marbling, blood vessels are visible on the skin as greenish-black streaks and eventually results in skin discoloration ranging from green to black, due to the formation of sulphmethemoglobin, which starts in 24 hours and becomes prominent in 36-48 hours.

 

iv. Postmortem lividity - Image 2. Livor mortis, also known as postmortem hypostasis or postmortem lividity, is a passive process of blood accumulating within the blood vessels in the dependent parts of the body as a result of gravity, causing a discoloration of the skin that varies from pink to dark purplish.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mummification: Occurs in dry or warm environments, preserving the body by desiccation.
  • Adipocere: Forms in warm, humid conditions through the hydrolysis of lipids, leading to a waxy transformation of body fat.
  • Marbling: Blood vessels become visible as greenish-black streaks due to sulphmethemoglobin formation, appearing within 24 hours and becoming prominent by 36-48 hours.
  • Postmortem Lividity: Blood accumulates in dependent body parts due to gravity, causing discoloration from pink to dark purple.

questions.text: Identify the type of injury given in the image below:(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Contusion

 

The image above shows a contusion.

 

  • A contusion, or bruise, is caused by a direct blow to the body that can cause damage to the surface of the skin and to deeper tissues as well depending on the severity of the blow.
  • It causes rupture of capillaries of the skin leading to the bruise

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Abrasion: Abrasion is a superficial injury where the skin is scraped off, usually due to friction against a rough surface. It does not typically involve deep tissue damage or significant bruising.

 

Option C. Laceration: A laceration is a tear or a jagged wound caused by blunt trauma. It usually has irregular margins and can vary in depth and severity.

 

Option D. Stab wound: A stab wound is a penetrating injury caused by a sharp object such as a knife. It is characterized by a small entry point and can vary greatly in depth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contusions, also known as bruises, are caused by blunt trauma that ruptures capillaries beneath the skin, leading to discoloration. They differ from abrasions, lacerations, and stab wounds in their mechanism of injury and appearance.

questions.text: You see these marks on the forearm of a woman who is being constantly harassed for dowry by her in-laws. What is this finding known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hesitation cuts

 

  • The image shows hesitation cuts.
  • It is a series of shallow cuts made by people considering a suicide attempt.
  • These wounds are often multiple, parallel, non-lethal cuts.
  • The throat, and wrist are the most common sites.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Grazed abrasion: Grazed abrasions occur when the skin is rubbed or scraped against a rough surface, leading to the removal of the superficial layers of the skin. This does not match the image shown, which depicts clean, linear cuts.

 

Option C. Laceration: Lacerations are deeper tears or cuts in the skin caused by blunt trauma. They are typically irregular and have abraded edges. The image shows clean, linear cuts, not consistent with lacerations.

 

Option D. Patterned bruise: Patterned bruises are caused by an object leaving a distinct pattern on the skin, such as from a belt or other implement. The marks in the image are linear and clean, not consistent with the diffuse and patterned nature of bruises.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hesitation cuts are superficial, parallel, and multiple cuts typically found in accessible areas like the wrist or throat, often indicating a cry for help or a practice attempt by individuals contemplating suicide.

questions.text: Cause of death in the position shown in the image below is: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Positional asphyxia

 

The position shown is Jack-knife position that leads to positional asphyxia (Restriction of lung expansion d/t abnormal position of the body). It is a position where the victim's thighs and knees are driven against the chest causing indirect compression of the chest and restriction of breathing movements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Wedging: Infant falls in the small gap between wall & bed and getting wedged there. It is a type of traumatic asphyxia.

 

Option B) Burking: Accused sits on chest of victim & closes mouth/ nostril as well. Its Mechanism is smothering combined with traumatic asphyxia.

 

Option D) Traumatic asphyxia: it is asphyxia due to restriction of lung expansion as a result of mechanical fixation of chest and not due to abnormal body position hence this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classification of Mechanical Asphyxia

 

1. Suffocation Asphyxia

  • Smothering
  • Gagging
  • Traumatic Asphyxia (Crush Asphyxia)
  • Positional Asphyxia (Postural Asphyxia)
  • Burking
  • Overlaying
  • Choking (Café Coronary)

 

2. Compression of neck

  • Hanging – force is body weight / body is suspended
  • Strangulation – force is anything other than body weight / no suspension.

 

3. Drowning

choices.text: Residual from barrel of gun
Gutter fracture of skull

questions.text: What is bullet wipe? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Residual from barrel of gun

 

Explanation:

 

A "bullet wipe" is a gray or black ring around an entrance bullet hole. The ring is formed by bullet lubricant, byproducts of propellant, traces of bullet metal, and residue in the gun barrel from previous use. It is caused due to residue from barrel of the gun.

 

Other options

 

Option B) Blackening: It occurs due to combustion (smoke) produced by burning of gun powder when a firearm is fired.

 

Option C) Gutter fracture of skull: It occurs due to a bullet passing adjacent to the skull

 

Option D) Tattooing: It occurs due to unburnt gun powder particles which gets deposited around the firearm wound.

 

Educational Objective

 

Bullet Wipe (Grease/Dirt Collar)

 

• Black/gray ring around gunshot wound.

• Composition includes bullet lubrication, paraffin, lead, barrel debris, and gun oil.

• Wider side of the ring indicates the direction of fire.

• More noticeable in shots from freshly oiled weapons.

• It  is dark in the center, fading towards the periphery.

• Prominent in clothing, termed as ‘bullet wipe.’

• It serve as proof of an entry wound in forensic analysis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male arrives in the emergency department after being exposed to an unidentified toxic substance given to him by a friend. His symptoms include dry mouth, urinary retention, and constipation. During the examination, his pulse rate is recorded at 140 beats per minute, and his pupils are observed to be dilated. Which substance is the most likely cause of these symptoms? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Belladona

 

The symptoms described, including dry mouth, urinary retention, constipation, increased heart rate, and dilated pupils, are consistent with anticholinergic toxicity. Belladonna, contains tropane alkaloids with anticholinergic effects. Features of belladonna are same as that of Datura, and both belong to Solanaceae family.

 

Other options

 

Option A) Heroin: It is an Opioid (CNS depressant) and have symptoms such as sedation, coma, decreased vitas (respiratory depression, low BP, low Heart rate, low temperature), and miosis. Whereas in the question there is high pulse rate, and dilated pupils.

 

Option B) Morphine: is also an Opioid, and will have similar features as that of heroin.

 

Option C) Malathion: is an organophosphate insecticide. It will have cholinergic symptoms, like Diarrhea, urination excessive, miosis, bradycardia, emesis, lachrymation, and salivation (Mnemonic DUMBELS). These are exactly opposite of those mentioned in question.

 

Educational Objective

 

Atropa Belladona

 

  • Solanaceae family: Datura stramonium, Atropa belladonna (deadly nightshade) and Hyoscyamus Niger (henbane) all belong to same family Solanaceae
  • Anticholinergic alkaloids: All of these plants have similar alkaloids, and all of these alkaloids have anticholinergic properties.
  • Active Principles: Examples of important active principles found in these alkaloids are Atropine, Hyoscine (scopolamine), Hyoscyamine.
  • Sign and symptoms: All of these have similar anticholinergic sign and symptoms. So, Atropa belladonna will also have features same as that of Datura: Dry hot skin, Dilatated pupils, Diplopia, Dry mouth, Decreased Body Secretions, Dysphagia, Dysarthria, Drunken gait, Delirium
  • Treatment is Physostigmine
  • Atropa Belladona have black berries as shown below:

questions.text: Paradoxical undressing is seen in? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hypothermia

 

  • Paradoxical undressing is seen in hypothermia victims.
  • The victims, despite low environmental temperatures, paradoxically remove their clothes due to a sudden feeling of warmth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heat stress: Heat stress leads to symptoms such as heat cramps, heat exhaustion, and heat stroke, characterized by elevated body temperature, dehydration, and sometimes loss of consciousness. It does not cause paradoxical undressing.

 

Option B. Voyeurism: Voyeurism is a psychiatric condition where an individual derives sexual pleasure from observing unsuspecting people who are naked, undressing, or engaging in sexual activities. It is unrelated to hypothermia or paradoxical undressing.

 

Option D. LSD overdose: LSD overdose can cause hallucinations, altered mental status, and sensory distortions. While individuals may engage in bizarre behaviors, paradoxical undressing is not a recognized symptom of LSD overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paradoxical undressing occurs in hypothermia victims who, despite experiencing extremely low temperatures, remove their clothing due to a sudden and misleading sensation of warmth.

questions.text:
The drowned dead body of a young man found in the sea and was brought in for postmortem examination. Which of the following findings do you see in seawater drowning? (INICET May 2021)

 

  1. Hypernatremia
  2. Hyponatremia
  3. Hyperkalemia
  4. Myocardial anoxia
  5. Hemodilution
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1 and 4   

 

 

Seawater Drowning Characteristics:

1. Hypernatremia: Seawater is hypertonic compared to the body fluids, leading to an increase in sodium levels in the blood.

4. Myocardial anoxia: Lack of oxygen due to drowning can lead to myocardial anoxia.

 

Fresh water drowning Vs Salt water Drowning

 

 

Other Options

 

2. Hyponatremia: Seen in freshwater drowning.

 

3. Hyperkalemia: Seen in freshwater drowning due to hemolysis.

 

5. Hemodilution: Seen in freshwater drowning due to absorption of water.

 

Educational Objective

 

DIFFERENCES BETWEEN FRESH WATER AND SALT WATER DROWNING

questions.text: Match the following poisons and their probable mechanism of action: (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:

A. Zinc chloride:

questions.text: A servant was sexually assaulted by her boss. There was presence of white stains on the clothes of the victim. Barberio's test was performed on the stains. Which of the following is detected by this test?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Spermine

 

  • Barberio’s test detects the presence of spermine (prostatic component of semen).
  • In this test the alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to dried seminal stain which produces the yellow needle shaped crystals are of spermine picrate.

 

Barberio’s test

 

  • Reagent: Picric Acid
  • Component of semen detected: Spermine (secreted from prostate gland)
  • Shape of crystals: Yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Acid phosphatase: It is detected in acid phosphatase test

 

Option C) Choline: It is detected in Florence test

 

Option D) Fructose: Produced by Seminal vesicles, but not commonly detected

 

Educational Objective

 

Tests for seminal stains

 

1) Presumptive test for seminal stains:

 

  • Fluorescence under UV light
  • Microchemical tests: ﻿﻿Florence test and ﻿Barberio's test   

 

2) Confirmatory Tests for Semen

 

  • Detection of complete sperm under the microscope (Best test)﻿﻿
  • Acid phosphatase test (second best test): It is produced by prostate gland. Acid phosphatase enzyme in semen is much higher concentration than other body fluids
  • ﻿﻿Creatine phosphokinase test: It is a component of Spermatozoa.
  • Prostate specific antigen
