questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding corporobasal index of the sacrum? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Breadth of first sacral vertebra X 100 / breadth of base of sacrum

 

  • Corporobasal index helps in determining the sex of the individual from the pelvis.
  • Corporobasal index = Breadth of first sacral vertebra x 100 / breadth of the base of the sacrum.
  • In males, it is >42 and in females, it is <42.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corporobasal index is calculated using the breadth of the first sacral vertebra and the breadth of the base of the sacrum, which helps in determining the sex of the individual.

 

Other Indices for Anthropometric Measurements:

questions.text: A young woman was found dead at home under mysterious circumstances. Her live-in partner was reported missing. These were the postmortem images taken by the forensic photographer. Which of the following is the likely cause of her death? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Throttling  

 

Manual strangulation, also known as throttling, is a type of asphyxial death where the perpetrator uses his hand to encircle and compress the front and side of the neck

 

In throttling, the following mechanisms may lead to death:

 

Autopsy findings:

 

  • Bruising on the neck

  • Abrasions of the neck

  • Contused tissues of the neck

 

Cause of death in throttling:

 

  • Occlusion of blood supply to the blood to the brain - carotid arteries

  • Occlusion of the airway leading to asphyxia

  • Carotid sinus pressure causing cardiac arrest

 

The given autopsy images are suggestive of throttling.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Strangulation: While strangulation is a general term that includes throttling, the specific mechanism in this case is manual strangulation, which is best described as throttling.

 

Option C. Hanging: Hanging typically presents with a ligature mark around the neck and different positional signs, which are not visible in this image.

 

Option D. Mugging: Mugging involves external pressure applied using limbs or objects, which generally do not produce the distinct bruising and abrasions seen in throttling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Throttling involves manual strangulation by applying pressure to the neck, causing bruises, abrasions, and contusions, and can lead to death by occlusion of blood supply or airway and pressure on the carotid sinus.

choices.text: Vicarious liability
Doctrine of negligent choice
Contributory negligence
Borrowed servant doctrine

questions.text: A surgeon lends his assistant to a physician; the new employer is responsible for his actions by? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Borrowed servant doctrine  

 

The borrowed servant rule is a legal doctrine in which an employer is held liable for the actions of a temporary employee. When an employee is being borrowed, the lending employer temporarily surrenders control over this worker and the borrowing employer temporarily assumes control.

 

Other options

 

Option A. Vicarious liability: Incorrect. Vicarious liability is a legal principle where an employer is held responsible for the actions of their employees while they are performing their job duties. However, it does not specifically address situations involving borrowed employees.

 

Option B. Doctrine of negligent choice: Incorrect. The doctrine of negligent choice involves holding someone liable for choosing an incompetent or unfit person to perform a task. This doctrine is not directly relevant to the situation described.

 

Option C. Contributory negligence: Incorrect. Contributory negligence refers to a situation where the injured party has, through their own negligence, contributed to the harm they suffered. It does not apply to the responsibility of an employer for the actions of a borrowed employee.

 

Educational objective

 

The borrowed servant doctrine holds that the borrowing employer assumes liability for the actions of an employee borrowed from another employer during the period of borrowing. This ensures that the temporary employer is responsible for supervising and controlling the borrowed employee.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman was taken by her neighbour to the emergency department after an incident involving her husband. She reported that during a domestic altercation, her husband swung an axe at her left arm. Upon examination, a significant injury was observed on her upper left arm. The wound appeared deep, with jagged and irregular edges. The surrounding area showed signs of bruising. Based on the clinical scenario, what type of wound is likely to be present on the patient's upper left arm? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chop wound 

 

A heavy object which is relatively sharp edged, e.g. axe produces chop wounds. Chop wounds have features of both sharp and blunt force injuries. They are characterized by deep, jagged, and irregular edges with surrounding bruising.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incised wound:

 

  • Produced by lighter weapons like knife, blades etc.
  • Margins are not contused and abraded. 
  • Destruction of underlying tissues is less as compared to cop wound.

 

Option C. Lacerated wound:

 

  • Lacerations can result from accidents, falls, or impact with blunt objects.
  • Lacerated wounds are not clean cut, whereas incised and chop wounds are clean cut.

 

Option D. Abrasion:  In abrasions only the superficial skin is damaged. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cut laceration / chop wounds: 

 

  • Produced by a heavy object which is relatively sharp edged, E.g. axe, chopper
    • It has features of both blunt force (bruised and abraded margins, irregular margins) and sharp force (clean margins)
    • A deep and wide cut over the body tissues.
    • Marked destruction of underlying tissues
    • Below image shows chop wound by axe:

questions.text: Identify the type of skull fracture in the given image? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fissured 

 

Image shows thin lines, which are not displaced. This is characteristic of fissured (linear) #

 

Fissured (linear) fractures present as thin, non-displaced lines and are the most common type of skull fracture, typically resulting from broad surface impacts, such as in road traffic accidents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ring Fracture: Caused by a fall from height, presenting as a fracture around the foramen magnum.

 

Option B. Depressed Fracture: Caused by heavy objects with a small surface area, takes the shape of the weapon.

 

Option D. Hinge Fracture: Divides the skull into anterior and posterior halves, often associated with motorcyclist injuries.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Skull fractures 

 

  1. Linear fracture/ primary fracture/ fissured fracture                                                 
    • Fracture looks like a thin line 
    • Due to striking with a broad surface, e.g. ground 
    • Most common skull fracture, 
    • Usually seen in Road traffic accident
       

  2. Depressed fracture/ signature fracture 

    • Due to a heavy objects with small surface area . e.g. hammer 
    • Takes the shape of the weapon 

     

  3. Indented fracture / ping pong fracture / ponds #
    • Skull is depressed like a ping pong ball 
    • Seen in infants 
       
  4. Gutter fracture 
    • Long narrow depressed fracture 
    • Bullet passing adjacent to skull 
       
  5. Sutural fracture / diastatic fracture 
    • Sutures separate
    • Seen In <3 yrs of age 
       
  6. Ring fracture 
    • Cause – fall from height 
    • # around foramen magnum 
    • Associated # of vertebrae 
       
  7. Hinge fracture / motorcyclist fracture 
    • Skull divided into anterior and posterior halves 
       
  8. Spider web fracture / mosaic fracture / comminuted fracture 
    • Multiple fractures of skull

questions.text: Match the following: (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

 

 1. Cocaine - b. White lady

 

  • Cocaine is known by various street names such as snuff, rock, crack, coke, snow, Cadillac, and white lady.

 

2. LSD - c. Purple wedge

 

  • LSD (Lysergic acid diethylamide) is referred to by names like acid, blotter acid, blue caps, blue dots, brown caps, crackers, Deeda, purple Owleys, purple wedges, The Beast, The Chief, The Ghost, The Hawk, and white lightning.

 

3. Abrus precatorius - d. Gunchi

 

  • Abrus precatorius, also known as Indian liquorice, prayer beads, crab's eye, weather plant, gulagunchi, ratti, and gunja, is a plant known for its toxic seeds.

 

4.  Capsaicin - a. Hunan hand

 

  • Capsaicin, the active component in chili peppers, is known to cause burning sensations on the skin, particularly the hands, leading to the term 'Hunan hand.'

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct matches are Cocaine with "White lady," LSD with "Purple wedge," Abrus precatorius with "Gunchi," and Capsaicin with "Hunan hand."

questions.text: Identify the gestational age of the fetus if the Crown Rump Length is 21 cm, length of lower limb is 10 cm, gestational age of the fetus will be: (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 6 to 7 months

 

Crown rump length + length of lower limb = crown heel length

 

According to the Rule of Haase

 

  • Age in months = Square root of crown-heel length (when the crown-heel length is 25 cm or less/ first 5 months).
  • Age in months = crown-heel length divided by 5 (when the crown-heel length is more than 25 cm/ last 5 months).

 

Here, crown heel length = Crown rump + lower limb length = 31 cm.

 

Hence, gestational age = 31 / 5 = 6-7 months.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Rule of Haase can be used to estimate gestational age from fetal measurements. For a crown-heel length greater than 25 cm, the gestational age is calculated by dividing the crown-heel length by 5.

choices.text: Sexual assault done by police officer

questions.text: According to POCSO, aggravated sexual assault includes: (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sexual assault done by police officer

 

An offence is treated as ‘aggravated’ when committed by a person in a position of trust or authority of child, such as a member of security forces, police officer, public servant, etc.

 

Other options

 

Option B) Threatening: it comes under sexual harassment in POCSO and not under aggravated sexual assault.

 

Option C) Gang penetrative sexual assault comes under aggravated penetrative sexual assault and not under aggravated sexual assault. Therefore, it cannot be correct in this case.

 

Option D) All of the above: since Option A and Option B are incorrect, it cannot be the answer.

 

Educational objective

 

POCSO

 

The POCSO act defines a child as any person below eighteen years of age. It defines various forms of sexual offenses which include:

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Sexual harassment - Threatening
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Sexual assault - Any act with sexual intent that involves physical contact without penetration.
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Aggravated sexual assault - Similar to sexual assault along with the criteria explained under the term aggravated
  4. ﻿﻿﻿Penetrative sexual assault - An act with sexual intent that involves physical penetration of the penis or any object into the vagina, mouth, urethra, or anus.
  5. ﻿﻿﻿Aggravated penetrative sexual assault - Similar to penetrative sexual assault along with the criteria explained under the term aggravated
  6. ﻿﻿﻿Pornography

 

When it comes to aggravated sexual assault, the crime must involve certain aggravating factors. For example: 

 

  • By a person in a position of the authority such as a police officer, relative, doctor
  • In the course of communal violence
  • On mentally & physically disabled
  • Gang sexual assault
  • Using deadly weapons
  • Causing grievous hurt

questions.text: A 33-year-old male with attempted poisoning was brought to the casualty in a drowsy state. His pulse was 140/min, respiratory rate -30/min. His ABG showed metabolic acidosis. Urine analysis showed Calcium oxalate crystals. Identify the likely poison?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ethylene glycol

 

The presence of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine is a key diagnostic sign of ethylene glycol poisoning. Metabolic acidosis and drowsiness is also indicating towards ethylene glycol poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Formaldehyde is ruled out because the patient’s symptoms like, metabolic acidosis, and the presence of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine, do not align with the typical effects of formaldehyde poisoning, which usually involves respiratory and mucous membrane irritation.

 

Option C. Paraldehyde While drowsiness and metabolic acidosis can be associated with paraldehyde poisoning, the presence of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine is a characteristic feature of ethylene glycol poisoning.

 

Option D. Methyl alcohol (methanol) While drowsiness and metabolic acidosis can be associated with methyl alcohol poisoning, the presence of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine is a characteristic feature of glycol poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethylene glycol poisoning

 

Ethylene glycol is the major constituent of antifreeze solutions. It is a clear, colorless, odorless, non-volatile liquid with a bitter-sweet taste.

 

Action: Ethylene glycol itself is not toxic, but the toxicity is due to metabolites glycolic and oxalic acids which inhibits oxidative phosphorylation.

 

  • Oxalic acid combines with calcium to form calcium oxalate crystals which accumulates in the proximal convoluted tubules causing renal failure.
  • Metabolic acidosis occurs from glycolic acid.
  • Ingestion of ethylene glycol produces CNS depression which may be accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and abdominal cramps. Metabolites of ethylene glycol produce severe metabolic acidosis and damage to the brain, heart, and kidneys

 

Treatment - Sodium bicarbonate, calcium gluconate, and 4-methyl pyrazole.

Ans. A. A-4, B-3, C-1, D-2

questions.text: Which is the first carpal bone to ossify? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Capitate

 

The capitate is the first carpal bone to ossify. The sequence and age of appearance of the carpal bones are important for determining skeletal maturity and age in forensic examinations.

 

Other options

 

Option A. Lunate: Appears at 4 years of age.

 

Option C. Hamate: Appears at 2 months of age, just after the capitate.

 

Option D. Scaphoid: Appears at 5 years of age.

 

Educational Objective

 

Age of appearance of carpal bones is given below:

 

 

Mnemonic:

 

  • Capitate is captain, hence comes first
  • Hamate sound like capitate, so comes immediately after it
  • Triquetral: Tri implies 3
  • Pisiform is Laziform so comes last

questions.text:
A 20-year-old girl was brought to the OPD. Genital examination revealed the findings as given below: (AIIMS NOV 2018)

 

  • Labia majora - separated
  • Labia minora- flabby
  • Fourchette tear present
  • Roomy vagina seen with intact hymen

 

What is true about this girl from the options below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. False virgin

 

The observed separated labia majora, flabby labia minora, roomy vagina, and a fourchette tear suggest penetration (sexual intercourse). So, the girl is not a virgin. Despite having sexual intercourse, the hymen is intact so it is a case of false virgin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. True virgin: Presence of labia majora, flabby labia minora, roomy vagina, and a fourchette tear suggest penetration (sexual intercourse). So, the girl is not true virgin.

 

Option C. Premenstrual change typically involve hormonal variations leading to breast tenderness, bloating, and mood swings rather than observable alterations in genital anatomy.

 

Option D. Molestation there would be sign of abrasions, bruising, edema, laceration or may have injuries to the vulva, hymen, vagina and the perineum. Since these signs are not present chances of molestation are slim

 

Educational  Objective:

 

Please note that the features will be same for a deflorate woman and a false virgin with the exception of presence of hymen in the latter.

questions.text: What is the cause of the lesion shown in the image below?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lightning strike

 

The image shows fern-like patterns, known as Lichtenberg flowers or filigree burns, which are characteristic of lightening injury.

 

Filigree burns:

 

  • Also called Arborescent or Lichtenberger’s flowers
  • They pathognomonic feature of lightening
  • Superficial, thin, irregular and tortuous markings on skin like branches of tree (fern like pattern).
  • They are caused by Slight staining of tissues by hemoglobin from lysed red blood cells (from superficial capillaries) along the path of electric current. Hence, they indicate the path taken by the discharge.
  • They do not follow the path of major blood vessels, but only follow the superficial capillaries
  • Though called Filigree Burns but they are not actually burns
  • They are transient erythema which appears within a few minutes to 1 hour of accident and gradually fades within 24 – 48 hours if the person survives.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Electrocution: Electrocution typically causes electrical burns which are different from the filigree burns seen in lightning strikes. These burns are usually deep and may show entry and exit wounds.

 

Option C. Marbling: Marbling refers to a postmortem change where blood vessels become visible as greenish-black streaks on the skin, occurring due to decomposition and is not related to electrical injuries.

 

Option D. Trickling down of acid: Acid injuries typically cause chemical burns with distinct, often more severe damage to the skin and tissues, and do not produce the characteristic fern-like patterns seen in lightning strikes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Filigree burns or Lichtenberg flowers are pathognomonic for lightning strikes and appear as superficial, fern-like patterns on the skin that fade within 24-48 hours.

questions.text: Bullet fingerprinting involves? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Both

 

Bullet fingerprinting / Ballistic finger printing:

 

  • Investigators using ballistic fingerprinting analyze a fired bullet or casing for scratches under a microscope. The markings, which — like fingerprints — are unique to each weapon, are then compared with those found on bullets used in separate shootings.
  • It involves both primary and secondary markings.

 

A. Primary markings (Class characteristics) occurs because bullet is slightly larger than the barrel. The primary markings are determined by Class characteristics are determined by manufacturing specifications, design and dimensions. They are most useful in identifying the make and model of the gun involved. Class characteristics in fired bullet identification would be:

 

i. Number, diameter and width of lands and grooves

ii. Depth of grooves

iii. Direction and degree of rifling twist

 

B. Secondary Markings (individual / accidental characteristics): These are formed due to Irregularities (imperfections) on the inner surface of barrel itself which are specific for that particular weapon. These irregularities are produced by sticking of particles of the bullet to the bore when shots are fired and is known as metallic fouling. They also result accidentally during the manufacturing process, usually microscopic in nature and have random distribution. They are useful in identifying the specific gun which was fired.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bullet fingerprinting utilizes both primary and secondary markings to identify a bullet, making it a comprehensive approach to forensic analysis in firearm-related investigations.

questions.text: From the options given below, which of these does not belong to the category of cardiac poison?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Atropa belladonna  

 

Atropa belladonna is not considered a cardiac poison. It is known for its anticholinergic properties and is part of the Solanaceae family, which includes Datura stramonium and Hyoscyamus niger. The active principles in these plants include atropine, hyoscine (scopolamine), and hyoscyamine, which exhibit anticholinergic effects.

 

Atropa Belladona

 

  • Solanaceae family: Datura stramonium, Atropa belladonna (deadly nightshade) and Hyoscyamus niger (henbane) all belong to same family Solanaceae

  • Anticholinergic alkaloids: All of these plants have similar alkaloids, and all of these alkaloids have anticholinergic properties.

  • Active Principles: Examples of important active principles found in these alkaloids are Atropine, Hyoscine (scopolamine), Hyoscyamine.

  • Align and symptoms: All of these have similar anticholinergic sign and symptoms, especially delirium.

  • Atropa Belladona have black berries as shown below:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aconite: Aconite is a cardiac poison. It affects the heart by causing arrhythmias and other cardiac disturbances.

 

Option B. Cerbera thevetia: Cerbera thevetia, also known as yellow oleander, is a well-known cardiac poison. It contains cardiac glycosides that affect the heart's rhythm and contractility.

 

Option C. Nicotiana tabacum: Nicotiana tabacum, or tobacco, contains nicotine, which has significant effects on the cardiovascular system, including causing hypertension and tachycardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiac Poisons (Mnemonic: DHONAQ)

  • Digitalis Purpurea (Digitalis)

  • HCN

  • Oleander (Kaner): 

         > White Oleander (Nerium Odorum)

         > Yellow Oleander (Cerebra Thevetia)

  • Nicotiana Tobaccum (Nicotine, Tobacco)

  • Aconite (Monk’s Hood, Mitha Zaher)

  • Quinine (Cinchona Plant)

questions.text:
Identify the findings in freshwater drowning? (INICET Nov 2020)

  1. Hemodilution

  2. Hypokalemia

  3. Hyponatremia

  4. Arrhythmia
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1, 3, 4

 

Rather than hypokalemia, there is an increase in potassium levels due to the release of intracellular potassium from swollen red blood cells. Hypokalemia is not typically a finding in freshwater drowning.

 

1. Haemodilution: Due to the excessive absorption of water through the alveolar-capillary membrane, the blood becomes diluted.

 

3. Hyponatremia: Haemodilution leads to a decrease in the concentration of sodium in the blood.

 

4. Arrhythmia: Electrolyte abnormalities caused by the haemodilution and resultant imbalance can lead to cardiac arrhythmias.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of freshwater drowning, we see

 

  • Hemodilution – Due to excessive fluid absorption

  • Hyponatremia – Due to hemodilution

  • Arrythmia – Due to electrolyte abnormalities

  • Hyperkalemia -Due to release of intracellular potassium from swollen RBCs

questions.text: Black foot is seen in which poisoning: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Arsenic

 

Blackfoot disease is an endemic peripheral vascular disease found among the inhabitants of a limited area on the southwest coast of Taiwan, where well water with a high concentration of arsenic causes peripheral vascular disease resulting in gangrene.

 

Other options are incorrect as the term Blackfoot disease is used only for arsenic

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Arsenic, cadmium, lead and mercury are the heavy metals which can cause peripheral vascular disease due to chronic poisoning. This leads to general clinical features of peripheral vascular disease (numbness in feet, rest pain etc.).
  • Blackfoot disease is a unique term given to peripheral vascular disease produced by chronic Arsenic poisoning. The name "Blackfoot" refers to the characteristic darkening and gangrene of the feet and lower legs. This ultimately leads to amputation.
  • In peripheral vascular disease caused by other heavy metals, gangrene is not a common manifestation

 

  • Above picture shows Blackfoot disease:

questions.text: A mentally challenged person bites his brother on the hand during a physical fight. All of the following statements are true about the given condition except? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Photograph is taken with two scales at right angle to one another in the vertical plane

 

The correct method for photographing bite marks is to use two scales placed at right angles to each other in the horizontal plane. This positioning ensures that the dimensions and orientation of the bite mark are accurately recorded for forensic analysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Swabs should be taken immediately after moistening with sterile water: Correct. Swabbing the bite mark is essential for collecting DNA evidence, which can be critical in identifying the biter.

 

Option B. It is most commonly caused by incisors and canines: Correct. Bite marks are typically made by the front teeth, especially the incisors and canines, which are used to grasp and tear.

 

Option D. 3D imaging is possible in the given condition: Correct. 3D imaging can be used to analyze bite marks more accurately, providing detailed information about the depth and pattern of the bite.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a human bite mark:

 

  • Swabs should be taken immediately after moistening with sterile water
  • It is most commonly caused by front teeth - incisors and canines
  • Photograph is taken with two scales at right angle to one another in the HORIZONTAL plane
  • 3D imaging is a valuable tool for analysis

choices.text: In Africanoids the cusps of molars are wide and deep with shovel shaped cusps in incisors
Upper third molar is most commonly absent in Mongolians
Prominent lingual ridge and labial ridge in mongols

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding teeth and ethnicity?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. In Africanoids the cusps of molars are wide and deep with shovel shaped cusps in incisors

 

The cusps of molars are wide and deep and cusps of incisors are shovel-shaped is typically seen in Mongoloid races not in Africanoids hence the statement is incorrect. In Africanoids there is presence of large teeth and often have more cusps on their molars, even up to eight, with two lingual cusps on the mandibular first premolars as an additional common finding.

 

Option B), Option C), Option D): these statements are correct as explained in the core concept above. The question is asking for the wrong statement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Key differences between race

questions.text: An autopsy was performed to find the cause of death of a person brought dead to the casualty. It showed abrasions on the neck, fracture of the thyroid cartilage and contused tissues in the neck. The cause of death is? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Throttling

 

The description of the autopsy findings, including abrasions on the neck, fracture of the thyroid cartilage, and contused tissues in the neck, typically indicates death resulting from external pressure on the neck. Throttling is the act of applying pressure to the neck, often by external force or someone’s hands, which can lead to these specific injuries.

 

Manual strangulation, also known as throttling, is a type of asphyxial death where the perpetrator uses his hand to encircle and compress the front and side of the neck.

 

Autopsy finding

 

External Findings:

 

  • Neck abrasions and bruises, often near the laryngeal prominence and jawline.
  • Signs of asphyxia: cyanosis, facial swelling, Tardieu’s spot, and bleeding from the nose and ears.
  • Finger bruises, usually 1.5–2 cm in size.
  • Extent depends on factors like pressure, assailant’s nails, and victim’s resistance.
  • Thumb marks are more prominent, and multiple abrasions may result from victim’s struggle.

 

Internal Findings:

 

  • Muscle tears.
  • Tongue damage.
  • Inward hyoid bone fracture.
  • Thyroid cartilage fracture.
  • Carotid sheath laceration and carotid artery damage.

 

The given autopsy images are suggestive of throttling as bruises and abrasions on the neck is seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hanging: In the case of hanging, there will be a ligature mark, which is not mentioned in the question.

 

Option C. Strangulation: Strangulation is a very generalized term used to describe deaths due to violent asphyxia. Eg- ligature strangulation, throttling etc. Since Throttling is already given in option B we can consider option C strangulation as ligature strangulation. It cannot be the answer as ligature mark is not seen.

 

Option D. Mugging: In mugging cases, the assailant typically compresses or squeezes the victim’s neck by using the crook of their elbow or knee. While a victim killed by this method may exhibit signs of asphyxia, a neck examination may not reveal any signs of violence because the compression is applied using the soft muscles of the arm or leg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Throttling involves manual strangulation by applying pressure to the neck, causing abrasions, contusions, and fractures in the neck structures.

questions.text: A farmer presented with history of ingestion of an unknown substance. He had increased sweating, lacrimation, diarrhea, muscle weakness, and tachycardia. What is the drug of choice for treatment? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Atropine

 

The above clinical scenario suggests organophosphate poisoning.

 

DOC for treatment- Atropine.

 

Though pralidoxime can also be given, but the main drug of choice is Atropine

 

 

SYMPTOMS:

 

 

MANAGEMENT:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcium gluconate: Calcium gluconate is used in cases of calcium deficiency or hyperkalemia.

 

Option C. Pralidoxime: Pralidoxime is a reactivator of acetylcholinesterase and is used in combination with atropine to treat organophosphate poisoning. However, it is not the primary drug of choice; atropine is.

 

Option D. Obidoxime: Obidoxime is also an acetylcholinesterase reactivator similar to pralidoxime, used in organophosphate poisoning, but not the primary drug of choice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of organophosphate poisoning presenting with symptoms like increased sweating, lacrimation, diarrhea, muscle weakness, and tachycardia, Atropine is the primary drug of choice for treatment. It acts by competitively inhibiting the muscarinic effects of acetylcholine.

questions.text: Which of the below agents cause hypertension when consumed?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cocaine

 

Cocaine is a stimulant (sympathomimetic) drug that typically leads to an increase in heart rate and blood pressure due to its effects on the cardiovascular system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Organophosphorus: Organophosphorus compounds are cholinesterase inhibitors and cause cholinergic symptoms like bradycardia, hypotension, salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation, gastrointestinal distress, and emesis (SLUDGE syndrome). They do not cause hypertension.

 

Option B. Phosphorus: Phosphorus poisoning typically leads to gastrointestinal symptoms (vomiting, diarrhea), jaundice, hepatic and renal failure. It does not cause hypertension.

 

Option C. Arsenic: Arsenic poisoning can cause a range of symptoms including gastrointestinal distress, peripheral neuropathy, skin changes (rain drop pigmentation), Mees' lines on nails, and long-term effects like cancer. It does not cause hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine is a sympathomimetic drug and has stimulant effects on CNS and cardiovascular system as mentioned below:

 

  • Agitation and Restlessness
  • Tachycardia / Palpitations
  • Hypertension
  • Dilated Pupils
  • Profuse Sweating
  • Hyperthermia
  • Restlessness
  • Paranoia and hallucinations.
  • Serious Cardiovascular Effects: Arrhythmias, Myocardial Infarction
  • Respiratory Distress: Rapid, shallow breathing and respiratory distress.
  • Seizures, Confusion and Altered Mental Status

choices.text: Tingling and numbness of hands and feet

questions.text: Amongst the options given below, which of these are not seen in cocaine poisoning? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Constricted pupils and bradycardia

 

Dilated pupils and tachycardia is seen with cocaine ingestion as it is a sympathomimetic (stimulant).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tingling and numbness of hands and feet: This is a common symptom due to the neurological effects of cocaine.

 

Option C. Hypertension: Cocaine causes vasoconstriction and increased heart rate, leading to hypertension.

 

Option D. Hyperthermia: Increased body temperature is a common finding due to excessive sympathetic stimulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Features of cocaine intoxication:

 

  • Early features – Stage of excitement:
  • Dry mouth, dysphagia, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypertension, dilated pupils, and increased temperature followed by convulsions, hallucinations, tingling, and numbness in the hands and feet.
  • Late features – Stage of depression – Respiration is depressed, excessive sweating, collapse, convulsions, and death.
  • Magnan’s symptoms / Cocaine bugs - Chronic cocaine users may have the feeling of insects crawling on their skin or the presence of grains of sand under the skin.
  • Ulceration of nasal septum seen due to sniffing cocaine in chronic abuse

questions.text: A girl runs away from home with her boyfriend and they get married. In court, she says that she is a major and is married to the boy. Identify the approximate age of the girl from the Xray picture of her pelvis? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. > 21 years

 

The ischial tuberosity in the X ray is fused, hence the age is > 21 years

 

Some students can get confused and are not able to distinguish whether ischial tuberosity has fused or not yet appeared. It is not possible that ischial tuberosity has not yet appeared because the upper end of femur (head, greater trochanter, lesser trochanter) has fused with shaft which occurs between 17- 19 years, whereas ischial tuberosity appears earlier at 16 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Femur

 

Upper end of Femur is composed of three centres:

 

  • Head – 1 yr (A)             
  • Greater Trochanter- 4 yr (A)
  • Lesser trochanter – 14 yr (A)          

 

These three centres fuse with shaft at 17- 19 yrs of age

 

Pelvis
